questions.question: Why do we add +1 in LCS DP when characters match?

answers.b: To extend an existing optimal subsequence

explanations.a: Incorrect. One match adds one unit of length.
explanations.b: Correct! A match at (i, j) extends the LCS of (i-1, j-1).
explanations.c: Incorrect. Movement is a side effect of the recurrence.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Table size is independent of matching.

questions.question: When characters don't match in LCS, why take max(dp[i-1][j], dp[i][j-1])?

answers.a: To skip one character from either string

explanations.a: Correct! We check which string's current character contributes less to the LCS.
explanations.b: Incorrect. LCS doesn't care about lexicography unless specified.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This step doesn't affect space complexity.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Recursion is a technique, not the goal.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of Hirschberg's algorithm for LCS?

answers.b: Reduced space complexity while allowing reconstruction

explanations.a: Incorrect. It actually takes more time (roughly double).
explanations.b: Correct! It achieves O(n) space while still letting us find the LCS string.
explanations.c: Incorrect. It is much more complex than standard DP.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It's still for two strings.

questions.question: What does a tie in the DP table (e.g., dp[i-1][j] == dp[i][j-1]) imply?

explanations.b: Correct! It means there's more than one path to the same maximum length.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Ties happen frequently even in non-identical strings.
explanations.d: Incorrect. A tie can occur at any length.

questions.question: Why is pure recursion alone inefficient for LCS and Rod Cutting?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Stack overflow is a limit, not the reason for inefficiency.
explanations.b: Correct! Without memoization, we solve the same state repeatedly.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Recursion handles any data type.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Recursion can find maximums easily.

questions.question: For very large inputs, what is the biggest limitation in standard O(n*m) DP?

explanations.a: Incorrect. CPU time is linear-quadratic, but memory is the first 'hard' limit hit.
explanations.c: Correct! A 100k x 100k matrix would require gigabytes of RAM.

questions.question: In Rod Cutting, why does the DP consider all possible first cuts?

answers.b: Because any length cut could lead to the optimal solution

explanations.a: Incorrect. Compilers don't dictate algorithm logic.
explanations.b: Correct! We must explore all i ∈ [1, n] to ensure optimality.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Experts prefer concise, correct code.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Memory use is unrelated to the loop range.

questions.question: Which statement is true for X='ABCBDAB', Y='BDCABA'?
Can the LCS length be greater than the length of the shorter string?

explanations.a: Incorrect. You cannot have a common sequence longer than the source material.
explanations.b: Correct! LCS length is bounded by min(length(X), length(Y)).
explanations.c: Incorrect. Even if they match, it equals the length, not exceeds it.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Data type doesn't change sequence logic.

questions.question: What is the space complexity of Rod Cutting with DP (Bottom-Up)?

explanations.a: Incorrect. We need a table to store revenues.
explanations.b: Correct! We only need an array of size n+1.
explanations.c: Incorrect. That would be for two-variable problems like LCS.
